 LOL. I used to eat ricers for lunch. My son and I went to an Import vs Domestic drag race in Mid-Michigan a few years back. My son had been trading posts on a racing forum with ricers that thought they had fast cars. They said that there would be lots of fast imports at the race, so we brought out my son's twin-turbo street legal Camaro to race them. After watching some pitiful qualifying passes by ricers with best times in the 11's, my son did the unexpected. He called out the fastest motorcycles to race him. There were 1/2 dozen Hyabusas there, but only one took the challenge. My son smoked him by three carlengths. 
 At the end of the official race, we were approached by the promoter and asked if we'd run the winner of the event, a turbocharged ricer. We agreed, spotted it 6 carlengths and passed it well before the 1/8mile. 
 The moral of the story: Every kid in a ricer thinks it's fast until it runs against American muscle. emoticon_xgood
 
 
I won't even rent an American car, let alone buy one. I have no faith in American automakers.

 Here's a public awareness bulletin for you in case your Tacoma is one of the trucks with its farme falling apart:
 

 Hi, folks, your friends at Toyota Motor Sales, here. We thought that we should bring to your attention a customer support program we're announcing today to extend warranty coverage on the frames of Toyota Tacoma trucks from model year 1995 through 2000.
 
 We've received reports that on a small number of Tacomas, frames may develop corrosion that goes beyond the normal surface rust that's commonly found on metal after years of exposure. This corrosion may extend to actual perforation of the frame's metal.
 In response, we're extending the rust-perforation warranty covering these trucks for a period of 15 years from each vehicle's original date of purchase, with no mileage limitation, for corrosion that results in perforation of the vehicle's frame material. 
 
 If you own one of these vehicles and you find that its frame may exhibit excessive corrosion to the point of metal perforation, we suggest that you take it to a Toyota dealership when you receive your notification letter so that it can be inspected. If inspection confirms frame corrosion damage perforation, we will either repair the vehicle or repurchase it. 
 Keep in mind that this is not a recall. Rather, it's an example of our commitment to our owners. 
 
 For a more detailed explanation of the situation, and of our repurchase program, please visit Toyota's Open Road at Newsroom : Our Point of View / Toyota.
 

 
 Funny, I don't "recall" (pun intended) any comparable announcements being made about the Ford F-150.

 My engine boiled over on the way home from buying it and I had to towed home!
 It would have been near impossible to return the car to the seller so I was stuck with it.
 I put a new head gasket in it and had the head skimmed plus I bought a new rad.
 When I put it back together I realised it had no boost controller fitted!
 
 I know I have a free flow exhaust, and an Apexi air intake but as for the stage one chip and walbro pump..I will check that at later stage.
 
 I still have other things to do to make it run sweet( I am waiting for some pistons to finish my caliper refurb as we speak)and I need to fit some hydraulic lifters..it sounds like a bag of spanners when I start it upemoticon_xdonno

trey

The interesting thing is that Buick was a pioneer of turbocharging in the '70s and '80s. Its 3.8 V6 turbo that started in the late '70s Regals and Rivs eventually became the powerhouse that allowed the Buick GNX to do 0-60 mph in 4.6 seconds with fuel injection in 1986.emoticon_xgood
 
 http://home.flash.net/~rjgeorge/images/79rivieracoty.JPG
JPSartre12

The Buick GN, when it was introduced was the fastest production car in the 1/4 mile during 1/2 of the year. The Corvette was faster the other six months.
 That was according to the old, IIRC, Motor Trend evaluation of the GN.
 
 That started the turbo craze in the US. As turbos became more readily available in the US, more cars started using them as opposed to superchargers because there wasn't the same parasitic HP loss associated with turning the compressor blades via belt and pulley.
 
 Now, you see more turbos on street cars than blowers. Someone mentioned boost controller above. We just put an AMS 1000 boost controller on our Camaro. It uses compressed gas to hold your setpoint and is fully programmable to 1/100 sec intervals.
 Internet Home of the AMS-1000 & AMS-500 Boost Controllers
 The only problem we have now is keeping the power on the track. At the last race we went to, we smoked the tires on 5 passes at various points in the 1/4 mile. Best pass to date was 8.77 @ 170mph, IIRC.
trey

The Buick GN, when it was introduced was the fastest production car in the 1/4 mile during 1/2 of the year. The Corvette was faster the other six months.
 That was according to the old, IIRC, Motor Trend evaluation of the GN.
 
 That started the turbo craze in the US. As turbos became more readily available in the US, more cars started using them as opposed to superchargers because there wasn't the same parasitic HP loss associated with turning the compressor blades via belt and pulley.
 
 Now, you see more turbos on street cars than blowers. Someone mentioned boost controller above. We just put an AMS 1000 boost controller on our Camaro. It uses compressed gas to hold your setpoint and is fully programmable to 1/100 sec intervals.
 Internet Home of the AMS-1000 & AMS-500 Boost Controllers
 The only problem we have now is keeping the power on the track. At the last race we went to, we smoked the tires on 5 passes at various points in the 1/4 mile. Best pass to date was 8.77 @ 170mph, IIRC.

 
 
 Ford were doing great things in the '80s with the 4 cylinder turbo. The 1979 2.3 turbo started on 132 hp with a 2 bbl carb, and by the late '80s was putting out 200 hp in the SVO Mustangs. However, cheap gas prices in the '90s meant this avenue was left fallow for too long.
 
 As a sign of American ingenuity STS turbo systems have an aftermarket set up mounted at the back of the car, routing exhaust gases under pressure into the engine, lowering underhood temps and not taking up space. It's pretty tight under the hood of most modern cars so this is a good development.:)

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Wouldn't you really rather have a Buick?
